Situation1: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: A conversion candidate's final, decisive study session before their Beit Din appearance is scheduled.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, red pen in hand. The hospital project was at a critical stage—today was the final safety review before construction began. Every line, every measurement, had to be perfect. Lives would depend on it. My phone buzzed. It was Miriam, the conversion candidate. Her last study session before the Beit Din was in an hour. She sounded anxious, needing reassurance and guidance. As her rabbi, I was expected to be fully present, to teach Torah with patience and care, to help her cross this spiritual threshold. But the hospital review demanded my undivided attention; a single oversight could mean disaster. My heart pounded as I stared at the clock, torn between my duty to safeguard physical lives and my responsibility to nurture a soul on the brink of transformation. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each expecting my complete devotion, each unwilling to wait.
